Hi Cesar,

Thanks for the reply.

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Cesar G. Mi=
guel" <cesar.gomes@...> wrote:
> What needs to be done:
> 
> - Documentatio=
n;
> - Fix the mess with some C/C++ extensions (they work, but not as
> bea=
utifully as the python version);
> - Better integration with CTRNNs and spi=
king models;
> - The idea is to be platform independent, but as the project=
 is
> developed on linux, I'm not sure how to compile those C/C++ extension=
s
> on windows.
> 
> We're planning to release version 1.0 until the end of=
 the year, and
> from there we will probably only be fixing bugs (I have so=
me other
> projects in mind). I hope it to be reliable enough for publicati=
on,
> but I need people to test it, criticize it, and report the results :)=


How about enabling the issue tracker on the project page and getting
some=
 of these tasks/bugs in there? I'm sure there are others like me
who would =
be interested in contributing.

I'd also be interested in being able to che=
ck out the latest code,
even if it still requires some cleaning up, as whil=
e it would be great
to be able to download a 1.0 release at the end of the =
year, that's
still some time away and time is a little short :)

Regards,

=
Stefan

>

e:
> > I work primarily in Python so I was pleased to see two implementatio=
ns

ython/) appears to be the

t one of the maintainers

> >
> =
> To the maintainers:
> >
> > - How complete is your NEAT implementation?
>=
 > - What tasks/bugs are still outstanding?
> >

 time into this but at the moment the 'issues'
> > section on the project d=
oesn't seem to be enabled so it's not clear

ked on.
> >
> > Assuming the algorithm implementation itself is mostly done=
 I'd also
> > be very interested in working on a GUI to aid with visualisat=
ion.
> >
> > A more general question: which NEAT implementation is generall=
y
> > considered to be the best to compare to when it comes to publications=
?
> > In order to compile Ken Stanley's reference C++ implementation I need=

> > to make a number of changes to satisfy the version of g++ that I have
=
> > here which concerns me as I may introduce mistakes in doing so.
> >
> >=
 My aim with the python implementation would be to bring it to a level
> > =
where it can be readily considered as suitable for use in comparisons
> > i=
n research; any thoughts on this?

ode.google.com/p/pyneat/
